newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: FORECAST-Singapore IT firms '96 profits seen flat.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Singapore IT firms '96 profits seen flat.

text.p: Most of Singapore's electronic firms are expected to report flat earnings growth for the 1996 financial year, hit by a global slump in the industry, analysts said on Monday.
Few companies are expected to buck the trend with double-digit growth, they said.
"The results we are waiting for are likely to be flat at zero to 5.0 percent in earnings growth," said Patrick Yau, analyst at Schroders Securities.
Ng Eng Hou at Keppel Securities said he expected most companies to post single digit net profit growth.
Most Singapore electronics firms are scheduled to report their earnings for the financial year ended December 1996 this month.
The global electronics industry suffered from excess inventories and sluggish demand last year.
Contract manufacturers, which make up the bulk of Singapore electronic firms, were likely to turn in dull results, the analysts said.
Earnings for end-product companies, like personal computer distributors and multimedia firms, were likely to be mixed, they said.
But the analysts singled out Venture Manufacturing as one of the few exceptions, a contract manufacturer expected to report double-digit growth.
"Venture makes high-value modules and intermediate components and is likely to escape the trend," said Yau.
He said Venture's net profits were likely to be 39 percent higher at Singapore S$30.46 million (US$21.45 million).
"They managed to hold their costs down and it has a diversified customer base and so would not be as badly hit as the others," said another analyst of Venture.
Views on PC manufacturers and distributors varied.
Some analysts projected flat results from Acer Computer International (ACI) while others were optimistic it would still turn in growth in the mid teens.
"I think Acer will be disappointing with zero to five percent growth," said an analyst at a foreign broking house.

Ng at Keppel Securities thought ACI, a unit of Taiwan's Acer Inc, could manage a 15 percent rise in net profit to S$35.7 million. But this was unspectacular compared to 1995's growth of 21.5 percent, he said.
Analysts said ACI, which distributes PCs in the Asia- Pacific region, saw its sales hurt by labour unrest in South Korea.
Its low-priced, stripped-down PCs did not have a flying start in 1996 but should do better in 1997, they said.
The analysts said IPC Corp was a wild card because of financial problems at its South Korean subsidiary.
"They may write off their Korean losses in 1996 to start 1997 on a clean slate, said Ng at Keppel.
He said if IPC managed to report profits, it would likely be S$1.0 to S$2.0 million. But it could lose around S$20 million.
Korea First Bank said in January that IPC Corporation (Korea) Ltd defaulted on repaying 570 billion won (US$657,000) worth of promissory notes.
IPC said in February it estimated its Korean exposure to be S$45.5 million.
Expectations for multimedia company Aztech, which had been hit by a copyright dispute with rival Creative Technology Ltd, were also mixed.
"Most people expect a loss for Aztech but I am projecting negative 37 percent growth at S$16 million," said Ng.
